title: 111_hr5400
content: The "Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010" allows for a work opportunity credit for certain recently discharged veterans. The "Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010" allows for a work opportunity credit for recently discharged and disadvantaged veterans. The amendment expands the definition of "recently discharged veteran" to include individuals who have served on active duty in the Armed Forces. The "Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010" provides a work opportunity credit for veterans who have served in the Armed Forces for more than 180 days, including those discharged for a service-connected disability and National Guard members who have served for more than 180 days of active duty. The "Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010" offers a work opportunity credit for veterans who have been discharged from duty within the last 5 years, excluding those who start working before the enactment of the Act. The "Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010" defines a disadvantaged veteran as someone receiving assistance under a nutrition program or entitled to compensation for a service-connected disability within a year of their hiring date. The "Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010" defines a disadvantaged veteran as someone discharged from active duty in the Armed Forces of the United States within a year of their hiring date, with at least 6 months of unemployment during that period. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are made to reflect these definitions. The "Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010" defines a disadvantaged veteran as someone discharged from active duty in the Armed Forces within a year of their hiring date, with at least 6 months of unemployment during that period. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 reflect these definitions. Additionally, pre-screening of recently discharged veterans is included in the Act, with no additional certification required for eligibility. The amendments made by the Veteran Employment Transition Act of 2010 apply to individuals hired after the enactment date. The Department of Defense and the National Guard must provide additional documentation to individuals discharged from active duty in the Armed Forces or released from National Guard duty after the enactment of this Act. The Department of Defense or the National Guard must provide additional documentation to individuals discharged from duty, including an informational briefing. The Department of Defense or the National Guard must provide documentation to discharged individuals, including an informational briefing on the work opportunity credit for recently discharged veterans. The Department of Defense or the National Guard must provide instructions to employers on how to use the work opportunity credit for recently discharged veterans, including the availability dates of the credit. Collaboration with the Internal Revenue Service is required for developing these instructions.
